title: Testing the Hubble-Lemaître Law from Another Place in the Universe
content:
The relationship you have been exploring between a galaxy’s recessional velocity and its distance is known as the Hubble-Lemaitre Law. But does this law apply only from our perspective in the Milky Way, or from other places in the Universe as well?

We will begin by viewing the data for five galaxies observed from the Milky Way Galaxy.

Select a galaxy from the menu by clicking on one of the star icons (on the left side of the Hubble plot) to see what the Hubble plots would look like for astronomers in each of the five galaxies.

Rotate and zoom the tool on the right to help visualize the relative positions of galaxies in space. Note: this does not imply that the Universe is rotating or expanding.

question.title: Question #1
question.label: In the Hubble plot, the data from galaxy observations all fall along a straight line. Are the galaxies actually positioned in space along a straight line?

question.title: Question #1
question.label: If alien astronomers living in Galaxy #2 (the blue star), were to view a Hubble plot from their position in the Universe, where would their galaxy appear on the plot?

options.label: next to the Milky Way Galaxy
options.value: next to the Milky Way Galaxy

options.label: the third dot from the origin
options.value: the third dot from the origin

question.label: Is the relationship between the distance of a galaxy and the velocity of a galaxy the same or different than what you observed from the Milky Way Galaxy? Explain.
How does the Hubble Constant for the observations made by the alien astronomers in Galaxy #2 compare to the Hubble Constant you measured from Earth (in the Milky Way Galaxy)?
Does this mean that the alien astronomers and Earth astronomers are observing the Universe expanding at the same rate or at different rates? If different, who observes the Universe expanding faster?
Do your observations suggest that astronomers at all locations in the Universe would observe that all galaxies are moving away from them?
Do your observations suggest that astronomers at all locations in the Universe would observe that the Universe is expanding at the same rate?
